Differentially Private Wireless Federated Learning Using Orthogonal Sequences

Xizixiang Wei   Tianhao Wang   Ruiquan Huang   Cong Shen   Jing Yang   H. Vincent Poor A preliminary version of this work was presented at the 2023 IEEE International Conference on Communications [1].Xizixiang Wei and Cong Shen are with the Charles L. Brown Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Virginia, USA. (E-mail: {xw8cw,cong}@virginia.edu). Tianhao Wang is with the Department of Computer Science, University of Virginia, USA. (E-mail: tianhao@virginia.edu). Ruiquan Huang and Jing Yang are with The Department of Electrical Engineering, The Pennsylvania State University, USA. (E-mail: {rzh5514,yangjing}@psu.edu). H. Vincent Poor is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Princeton University, USA. (E-mail: poor@princeton.edu).
Abstract

We propose a privacy-preserving uplink over-the-air computation (AirComp) method, termed FLORAS, for single-input single-output (SISO) wireless federated learning (FL) systems. From the perspective of communication designs, FLORAS eliminates the requirement of channel state information at the transmitters (CSIT) by leveraging the properties of orthogonal sequences. From the privacy perspective, we prove that FLORAS offers both item-level and client-level differential privacy (DP) guarantees. Moreover, by properly adjusting the system parameters, FLORAS can flexibly achieve different DP levels at no additional cost. A new FL convergence bound is derived which, combined with the privacy guarantees, allows for a smooth tradeoff between the achieved convergence rate and differential privacy levels. Experimental results demonstrate the advantages of FLORAS compared with the baseline AirComp method, and validate that the analytical results can guide the design of privacy-preserving FL with different tradeoff requirements on the model convergence and privacy levels.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning; Differential Privacy; Orthogonal Sequences; Convergence Analysis.

I Introduction

Real-world data generated or collected by edge devices enables various machine learning (ML) applications. For certain privacy-sensitive tasks, users prefer to keep their data locally instead of uploading to cloud servers. Federated learning (FL) [2, 3] has emerged as a distributed learning paradigm that caters to this growing trend, and is able to train a global ML model across all local datasets without the server having direct access to client data.

The local training nature of FL leads to massive communication costs, as an FL task consists of multiple learning rounds, each of which requires uplink and downlink model exchange between clients and the server. Compared with downlink broadcasting, uplink communication is more challenging in FL when communication is over the wireless medium [4, 5, 6]. Due to the stringent power constraints at mobile devices, channel noise and fading have a more conspicuous impact on uplink communications. More importantly, significant scalability challenges arise from the large number of clients in FL versus limited uplink communication resources. Uplink communication is known to be one of the key bottlenecks of wireless federated learning [2].

To tackle the scalability problem, over-the-air computation (also known as AirComp) mechanisms have been proposed. Instead of decoding individual local models of clients and then aggregating, AirComp allows multiple clients to transmit uplink signals in a naturally superpositioned fashion over a wireless medium, and decodes the average global model directly at the FL server. AirComp dramatically improves the scalability of wireless FL, and reduces the signal processing latency. Therefore, AirComp is regarded as a key technology for FL in wireless networks and has been investigated extensively [7, 8, 9, 10].

The most popular AirComp method is based on channel inversion power control [7], which “inverts” the fading channel at each transmitter so that the aggregated model can be directly obtained at the server. Variants and enhancements of AirComp have been studied, and a literature review can be found in Section II-A. Yet, a fundamental limitation of the existing methods is that they mostly require channel state information at the transmitter (CSIT). Enabling CSIT in wireless communication systems is complicated and is substantially harder than obtaining the channel state information at the receiver (CSIR). Moreover, channel inversion based on CSIT is well known to “blow up” when one of the users’ channels is in deep fade [11]. Hence, exploring CSIT-free AirComp methods becomes attractive[12].

Meanwhile, amidst a growing focus on data security, the importance of safeguarding individuals’ personal information has become increasingly emphasized. Although FL intuitively helps protect client privacy by keeping training data locally and never sharing it with the server, private information can still be leaked to some extent by analyzing the ML model parameters trained and uploaded by the clients [13, 14, 15]. To address the privacy concern, a natural way is to add (artificial) noise to ML model parameters in the upload phase of FL, whose privacy properties can be mathematically characterized using differential privacy (DP) [16].

AirComp has the potential to provide DP guarantee at no extra cost due to the inherent natural noise in the wireless channel. Heuristically, different DP levels can be guaranteed by controlling the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), and thus the effective channel noise level, at the receiver side. Yet, most of the literature on AirComp rarely characterizes the achievable privacy in a mathematically rigorous fashion. A literature review can be found in Section II-B. Moreover, we note that the existing literature focuses only on item-level DP in wireless FL, while client-level DP (also known as user-level DP) [17] is a new metric that is particularly worth investigating for FL, which is largely missing.

To simultaneously remove the CSIT requirement of AirComp and address the privacy challenge, we propose FLORAS – Federated Learning using ORthogonAl Sequences, a novel uplink wireless physical layer design for FL by leveraging the properties of orthogonal sequences. On the communication design, FLORAS preserves all the advantages of AirComp while removing the CSIT requirement. From the perspective of privacy, FLORAS achieves desired DP guarantees (both item-level and client-level) by adjusting the number of used orthogonal sequences, making it much simpler and providing more flexibility to trade off privacy and utility.

The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We propose FLORAS for uplink communications in single-input single-output (SISO) wireless FL systems. FLORAS enjoys all the advantages of AirComp, yet without the CSIT requirement. In particular, orthogonal sequences allow the base station (BS) to obtain individual CSIR via a single pilot, by which global ML model parameters can be estimated via simple linear projections. Therefore, FLORAS significantly reduces the channel estimation overhead. Different from the channel inversion power control, FLORAS allows the transmit power to be independent of the channel realizations, which avoids increasing the dynamic range of the transmit signal and improves the power efficiency.

  • •

    By adjusting the number of orthogonal sequences in the system configuration, the novel signal processing technique in FLORAS produces Cauchy effective noise to the decoded global model, which empowers flexible item-level and client-level DP guarantees. Moreover, a new FL convergence bound based on the truncated Cauchy noise is derived, which allows us to characterize the tradeoff between the model convergence rate and the achievable DP levels.

  • •

    We conduct extensive experiments based on real-world datasets to evaluate the performance of FLORAS. Numerical results demonstrate the performance advantages of FLORAS compared with the channel inversion method and validate our theoretical analysis by achieving tradeoffs between model convergence and DP.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Literature review is presented in Section II. Section III introduces the FL pipeline and the uplink communication model. The proposed FLORAS design is detailed in Section IV. The DP guarantee and convergence analysis of FLORAS are presented in Section V and Section VI, respectively. Experimental results are reported in Section VII, followed by the conclusion of our work in Section VIII.

II Related Work

II-A AirComp for FL

The AirComp approach [7, 8, 9, 10] exploits the inherent signal superposition characteristics of a wireless multiple access channel to efficiently perform sum/average computations. This methodology can be considered as a special instance of computation over multiple access channels, as outlined by [18]. The approach has garnered significant attention due to its ability to minimize uplink communication costs, irrespective of the number of participating clients in FL. The exploration of client scheduling, along with various power and computation resource allocation techniques, has been investigated by [19, 20, 21, 22, 23]. Several studies have provided convergence guarantees for AirComp under diverse practical constraints and types of heterogeneity [24, 25, 26, 27, 28]. Efforts also have been made to reduce the CSIT requirement of AirComp. [29] relaxes full CSIT by utilizing only the phase information of the channel. Notably, [30] and [4] present CSIT-free AirComp methods that leverage channel orthogonality, although their effectiveness is limited to massive MIMO systems.

II-B Differential Privacy for FL

DP-SGD has been widely regarded as a standard approach to train a differentially private ML model [31]. Along with its variants[32, 33], recent years have also witnessed increased efforts on DP for distributed learning systems, including the clipping technique in [34, 35], the subsampling principle in [36], and random quantization in [37]. In the category of exploiting the channel noise for differentially private FL, [38] proposes an AirComp design to achieve DP by adjusting the effective noise; [39, 40] investigate adding noise and power allocation in non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) systems; [41] considers DP amplification via user sampling and wireless aggregation; [42] applies it to personalized FL. [43] jointly optimizes the latency and DP requirements of FL, and [44] discusses the tradeoff among privacy, utility, and communication.

III System Model

III-A FL Model

The FedAvg framework [2] keeps client data locally, and the global model is obtained at the parameter server by the composition of multiple learning rounds. One of the key characteristics of FL is partial clients participation, i.e., only a portion of clients are selected in a single learning round for model upload. Here, we assume that K𝐾K of total M𝑀M clients are uniformly randomly selected during each learning round for the FL task. To simplify the notation, we use the subscript k=1,⋯,K𝑘1⋯𝐾k=1,\cdots,K to indicate the participating K𝐾K clients during a given learning round, acknowledging that they could correspond to different clients in different rounds.

A typical wireless FL pipeline iteratively executes the following steps in the t𝑡t-th learning round.

This work focuses on steps 333 and 444 in the FL pipeline. In particular, we leverage the unique properties of orthogonal sequences, which leads to an efficient FL uplink communication design with DP guarantees.

III-B Communication Model

In each learning round, since there are K𝐾K active clients, the uplink communication between clients (mobile devices) and the parameter server (base station) can be modeled as over a fading multiple access channel. Consider a cell with a single-antenna BS and K𝐾K single-antenna users involved in one round of the aforementioned FL task. The communication system leverages orthogonal sequences for uplink transmissions. Note that one of the most popular implementations of the orthogonal sequence-based system is code-division multiple access (CDMA). We assume a spreading sequence set 𝒜={𝐚1,⋯,𝐚k,⋯,𝐚N}𝒜subscript𝐚1⋯subscript𝐚𝑘⋯subscript𝐚𝑁\mathcal{A}=\{{\bf a}_{1},\cdots,{\bf a}_{k},\cdots,{\bf a}_{N}\} containing N𝑁N unique spreading sequences (N≥K𝑁𝐾N\geq K), where each spreading sequence is denoted as 𝐚k=[a1,k,⋯,aL,k]Tsubscript𝐚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑎1𝑘⋯subscript𝑎𝐿𝑘𝑇{\bf a}_{k}=[a_{1,k},\cdots,a_{L,k}]^{T} and L𝐿L is the length of the spreading sequence. Each user is (randomly) assigned with a unique spreading sequence 𝐚ksubscript𝐚𝑘{\bf a}_{k} from 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} as its signature.

We assume that the BS only has knowledge of the entire spreading sequence set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, without knowing the specific signature of each user. We emphasize that this restriction is consistent with our goal of guaranteeing user privacy – BS cannot identify users or decode individual models based on their spreading sequences. We will discuss the details of the spreading sequence assignment mechanism in Section V-D.

In the uplink communication, each client transmits the differential between the received global model and the computed new local model:

𝐱tk=𝐰t−𝐰t+1k∈ℝd,∀k=1,⋯,K.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝑘subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑for-all𝑘1⋯𝐾{\bf{x}}_{t}^{k}={\bf w}_{t}-{\bf w}_{t+1}^{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\;\;\forall k=1,\cdots,K.

The BS aims at estimating 𝐱t≜∑k=1K𝐱tk≜subscript𝐱𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝑘{\bf x}_{t}\triangleq\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\bf{x}}_{t}^{k}.

as the normalized transmit signal. We emphasize that we do not make any specific assumption on the fading distribution throughout this paper. Note that since the model differential parameters are real signals, we only need to consider the real parts of channel coefficients and noise. Although one-dimensional (real) modulation cannot fully leverage the channel degrees of freedom, it is consistent with the fact that binary phase-shift keying (BPSK) is the most common modulation scheme in CDMA systems [11]. In addition, focusing on the real dimension makes the subsequent discussion easier and highlights our contribution better. Also, as we detail later in Remark 2, we can leverage full channel gain at an affordable cost of partial CSIT.

𝐱~t≜Cmax,tC​𝗑~t+∑k=1Kμk≜subscript~𝐱𝑡subscript𝐶𝑡𝐶subscript~𝗑𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜇𝑘\tilde{\bf x}_{t}\triangleq\frac{C_{\max,t}}{C}\mathsf{\tilde{x}}_{t}+\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mu_{k}

Throughout the paper, we assume that all users are synchronized in frames, which can be achieved by the BS sending a beacon signal to initialize uplink transmissions [46].

IV FLORAS

We present the FLORAS design for uplink communications in wireless FL, and give some preliminary analysis.

IV-A Algorithm Design

FLORAS is a four-step protocol detailed as follows.

Step 1: Uplink channel estimation.    The BS first schedules all participating users to transmit a common pilot s𝑠s simultaneously. The received signal is

𝐲s=∑k=1K𝐚k​hk​s+𝐧s.subscript𝐲𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐚𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘𝑠subscript𝐧𝑠\displaystyle{\bf y}_{s}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\bf a}_{k}h_{k}s+{\bf n}_{s}.

The BS can utilize 𝐲ssubscript𝐲𝑠{\bf y}_{s} and the complete set of orthogonal sequences 𝒜={𝐚1,⋯,𝐚N}𝒜subscript𝐚1⋯subscript𝐚𝑁\mathcal{A}=\{{\bf a}_{1},\cdots,{\bf a}_{N}\} to estimate the channel gain coefficients. For the K𝐾K spreading sequences that are actually adopted by the user222Without loss of generality, we assume the first K𝐾K spreading sequences from the set are selected. This assumption is made to ease the notation., we have

h^k=𝐚kT​[∑i=1K𝐚i​hi​s+𝐧s]s=hk+𝐚kT​𝐧ss,∀k=1,⋯,K.formulae-sequencesubscript^ℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑘𝑇delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝐚𝑖subscriptℎ𝑖𝑠subscript𝐧𝑠𝑠subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑘𝑇subscript𝐧𝑠𝑠for-all𝑘1⋯𝐾\hat{h}_{k}=\frac{{\bf a}_{k}^{T}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{K}{\bf a}_{i}h_{i}s+{\bf n}_{s}\right]}{s}=h_{k}+\frac{{\bf a}_{k}^{T}{\bf n}_{s}}{s},\forall k=1,\cdots,K.

For the N−K𝑁𝐾N-K spreading sequences that are not selected by any user, the BS obtains

IV-B Preliminary Analysis

In the high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) regime, where the channel fading effect dominates the noise, we have 𝔼​[‖𝐚kT​𝐧s‖2]≪𝔼​[‖hk‖2]much-less-than𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐚𝑘𝑇subscript𝐧𝑠2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptℎ𝑘2\mathbb{E}[\left\|{\bf a}_{k}^{T}{\bf n}_{s}\right\|^{2}]\ll\mathbb{E}[\left\|h_{k}\right\|^{2}]. Therefore, we can establish the following approximation for the estimated model in Step 444:

x~i≈∑k=1Kxki+∑k=K+1N𝐚kT​𝐧i𝐚kT​𝐧s,∀i=1,⋯,d,formulae-sequencesubscript~𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘𝐾1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑘𝑇subscript𝐧𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑇𝑘subscript𝐧𝑠for-all𝑖1⋯𝑑\tilde{x}_{i}\approx\sum_{k=1}^{K}x_{k}^{i}+\sum_{k=K+1}^{N}\frac{{\bf a}_{k}^{T}{\bf n}_{i}}{{\bf a}^{T}_{k}{\bf n}_{s}},\;\;\forall i=1,\cdots,d, (3)

where ∑k=K+1N𝐚kT​𝐧i𝐚kT​𝐧ssuperscriptsubscript𝑘𝐾1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑘𝑇subscript𝐧𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑇𝑘subscript𝐧𝑠\sum_{k=K+1}^{N}\frac{{\bf a}_{k}^{T}{\bf n}_{i}}{{\bf a}^{T}_{k}{\bf n}_{s}} denotes the dominant noise of the received global model parameters333Note that this approximation drops the minor noise term, which results in that the DP guarantee in the later discussion is a lower bound of the true DP level of FLORAS, i.e., we achieve better DP than that computed in this paper.. The distribution of this post-processing noise is not straightforward, and we next present Lemma 1 to establish that the noise term is a Cauchy random variable.

Lemma 1.

Define γ≜N−K≜𝛾𝑁𝐾\gamma\triangleq N-K. For IID Gaussian random vector 𝐧i,𝐧s∼𝒩​(0,σ2L​𝐈)similar-tosubscript𝐧𝑖subscript𝐧𝑠𝒩0superscript𝜎2𝐿𝐈{\bf n}_{i},{\bf n}_{s}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\frac{\sigma^{2}}{L}{\bf I}), random variable

Cauchy distribution is known as a “fat tail” distribution, as the tail of its PDF decreases proportionally with 1/x21superscript𝑥21/x^{2}. Lemma 1 suggests that, for a fixed K𝐾K, a larger spreading sequence set will result in a heavier tail in the Cauchy noise. Therefore, we can adjust the size of the spreading sequence set to induce different additive Cauchy noise in (3). We will discuss the effect of Cauchy noise on DP and convergence in Sections V and VI, respectively.

A few remarks about FLORAS are now in order.

Remark 1 (Advantages over the channel inversion method).

Compared with the widely studied channel inversion-based AirComp design, FLORAS does not require CSIT for uplink communications, which greatly reduces the communication overhead. This is especially attractive for Internet-of-Things (IoT) applications with massive devices. Moreover, in SISO systems, the maximum uplink transmit power of each user in the channel inversion-based methods is usually limited by the worst channel gain. As a result, the received SNR of the global model and the efficiency of power amplifiers (PAs) will significantly decrease, if one of the client channels experiences deep fading [11]. Thanks to the orthogonality of spreading sequences, FLORAS allows the transmit power to be independent of small-scale fading channel realizations, and thus avoids increasing the dynamic range of the transmit signal, which improves the power efficiency of PAs.

Remark 2 (Leverage full channel degrees of freedom).

As mentioned before, real modulation cannot exploit full degrees of freedom of the complex channel. To address this limitation, we can borrow the idea of [29]. Specifically, the fading channel between each client and the BS can be written as

hk=h~k​ej​ϕk,∀k=1,⋯,K,formulae-sequencesubscriptℎ𝑘subscript~ℎ𝑘superscript𝑒𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘for-all𝑘1⋯𝐾h_{k}=\tilde{h}_{k}e^{j\phi_{k}},\;\;\forall k=1,\cdots,K,

where h~k≜|hk|∈ℝ+≜subscript~ℎ𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscriptℝ\tilde{h}_{k}\triangleq|h_{k}|\in\mathbb{R}_{+} and ϕk≜∠​hk∈[0,2​π)≜subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘∠subscriptℎ𝑘02𝜋\phi_{k}\triangleq\angle h_{k}\in[0,2\pi) represent channel amplitude (gain) and phase, respectively. For a given xkisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖x_{k}^{i}, client k𝑘k transmits symbol xki​e−j​ϕksuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖superscript𝑒𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘x_{k}^{i}e^{-j\phi_{k}}, where e−j​ϕksuperscript𝑒𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘e^{-j\phi_{k}} is the phase correction term as suggested in [29]. Hence the received signal at the BS can be written as

𝐲i=∑k=1K𝐚k​hk​e−j​ϕk​xki+𝐧i=∑k=1K𝐚k​h~k​xki+𝐧i,∀i=1,⋯,d.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐲𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐚𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘superscript𝑒𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝐧𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐚𝑘subscript~ℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝐧𝑖for-all𝑖1⋯𝑑{\bf y}_{i}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\bf a}_{k}h_{k}e^{-j\phi_{k}}x_{k}^{i}+{\bf n}_{i}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\bf a}_{k}\tilde{h}_{k}x_{k}^{i}+{\bf n}_{i},\forall i=1,\cdots,d.

By phase correction, the imaginary part of hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} is projected to the real domain and the full channel gain can be leveraged without sacrificing any other advantages of FLORAS. We note that same as in [29], this approach requires each client k𝑘k to have the channel phase information ϕksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘\phi_{k}, which is weaker than the complete CSIT hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} but stronger than the standard FLORAS.

Note that we consider the imperfect channel estimation previously in Step 222 for uplink communication. For simplicity, we assume that each client has perfect partial CSIT (channel phases) obtained from downlink channel estimation here. One reason for this different consideration is that the transmit power at the BS is usually much larger than those at devices, which naturally ensures more accurate downlink channel estimation than uplink. Additionally, even if the phase correction term suffers from estimation error, as long as the error is within [−π/2,π/2)𝜋2𝜋2[-\pi/2,\pi/2), the proposed design is still valid [29], only at a cost of some channel gain lost.

Remark 3 (Extensions on NOMA systems).

Another limitation of FLORAS is that the number of orthogonal spreading sequences is fixed for a given sequence length. To expand the size of set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, the system would need to adopt longer spreading sequences, which consumes more bandwidth. We first note that although there may exist a large number of clients in an FL task, the number of actively participating clients in each learning round is usually relatively small (due to client selection), which implies the bandwidth cost will not be too significant for our design. Second, as an alternative, the system can adopt non-orthogonal spreading sequences to improve the scalability without the cost of extra bandwidth. Applying non-orthogonal spreading sequences is consistent with non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) systems, which is an emerging technology for massive machine-type communications (mMTC) applications. For non-orthogonal spreading sequences, the requirement in (1) becomes

𝔼​[𝐚iT​𝐚i]=1,∀i​ and ​𝔼​[𝐚iT​𝐚j]=0,∀i≠j,formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑖𝑇subscript𝐚𝑖1formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖 and 𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑖𝑇subscript𝐚𝑗0for-all𝑖𝑗\mathbb{E}\left[{\bf a}_{i}^{T}{\bf a}_{i}\right]=1,\;\;\forall i\text{~{}~{}and~{}~{}}\mathbb{E}\left[{\bf a}_{i}^{T}{\bf a}_{j}\right]=0,\;\;\forall i\neq j,

which can be achieved by random Gaussian vectors. Note that Lemma 1 still holds for non-orthogonal spreading sequences, since it allows an arbitrary covariance matrix of random Gaussian vectors Y𝑌Y and Z𝑍Z. Non-orthogonal spreading sequences will introduce inter-symbol interference besides noise when decoding the global model parameters in Step 444. Therefore, the convergence bound developed in Section VI can be regarded as a lower bound for NOMA systems.

V Differential Privacy Analysis

In this section, we analyze the DP level achieved by FLORAS. We begin by introducing the basic concepts of DP in FL, and then prove that FLORAS achieves different levels of DP via the adjustment of the size of spreading sequence set N𝑁N and the number of involved clients K𝐾K. Both item-level and client-level DP are analyzed. The DP guarantee not only considers multiple sources of randomness in wireless FL, including random mini-batch in SGD, the Cauchy noise, and the random client participation, but also reveals the influence of multiple learning rounds.

V-A Preliminaries

We first introduce the concept of neighboring datasets. We say that two datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} are neighboring, written as 𝒟∼𝒟′similar-to𝒟superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}\sim\mathcal{D}^{\prime}, if they differ in at most one sample. Based on this concept, we state the standard definition of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP as follows.

Definition 1 ((ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP [16]).

A randomized algorithm ℳ:Xn→ℛ:ℳ→superscript𝑋𝑛ℛ\mathcal{M}:X^{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} provides (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP with 0≤δ<10𝛿10\leq\delta<1, if for all pairs of neighboring datasets 𝒟∼𝒟′similar-to𝒟superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}\sim\mathcal{D}^{\prime} and all measurable sets of outcomes S⊆ℛ𝑆ℛS\subseteq\mathcal{R}, we have

ℙ​[ℳ​(𝒟)∈S]≤eϵ​ℙ​[ℳ​(𝒟′)∈S]+δ.ℙdelimited-[]ℳ𝒟𝑆superscript𝑒italic-ϵℙdelimited-[]ℳsuperscript𝒟′𝑆𝛿\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})\in S]\leq e^{\epsilon}\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\in S]+\delta.

We say that a randomized algorithm achieves ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP (also known as pure DP) if it satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP with δ=0𝛿0\delta=0. The common interpretation of δ𝛿\delta is the “leakage probability”, i.e., (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP “except with probability δ𝛿\delta”.

We next introduce the definition of Rényi DP [48]. As a generalization of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, it can help us obtain a tighter (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP bound converted from its composition, which is particularly attractive in FL due to its multiple learning rounds.

Definition 2 ((α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-Rényi DP [48]).

A randomized algorithm ℳ:Xn→ℛ:ℳ→superscript𝑋𝑛ℛ\mathcal{M}:X^{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} is said to provide (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-Rényi DP, if for any pair of neighboring datasets 𝒟∼𝒟′similar-to𝒟superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}\sim\mathcal{D}^{\prime} it holds that

Dα(ℳ(𝒟)||ℳ(𝒟′))≤ϵ,D_{\alpha}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})||\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon,

where

Dα(ℳ(𝒟)||ℳ(𝒟′))≜1α−1log∫−∞+∞P(x)αQ(x)1−αdxD_{\alpha}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})||\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\triangleq\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}P(x)^{\alpha}Q(x)^{1-\alpha}dx

is the Rényi divergence. Specially, for α=+∞𝛼\alpha=+\infty, we have

D∞(ℳ(𝒟)||ℳ(𝒟′))=supx∈supp​QlogP​(x)Q​(x).D_{\infty}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})||\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))=\sup_{x\in\text{supp}Q}\log\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}.

In the AirComp FL design, decoding the global model from the received signal can be regarded as a randomized mechanism on 𝒟=⋃k=1M𝒟k𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑀subscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}=\bigcup_{k=1}^{M}\mathcal{D}_{k}, where 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is the union of the local datasets of all M𝑀M clients throughout the whole FL task. We denote this randomized mechanism as

ℳ​(𝒟)≜𝐱~t=g​(𝒟)+𝐧t,≜ℳ𝒟subscript~𝐱𝑡𝑔𝒟subscript𝐧𝑡\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})\triangleq\tilde{{\bf x}}_{t}=g(\mathcal{D})+{\bf n}_{t}, (4)

where g​(𝒟)=𝐱t𝑔𝒟subscript𝐱𝑡g(\mathcal{D})={\bf x}_{t} is the noise-free summation of model differentials at the t𝑡t-th learning round, and 𝐧tsubscript𝐧𝑡{\bf n}_{t} is a random noise following a certain distribution. The randomness of the mechanism comes from the random client participation, random mini-batch SGD, and the random noise.

To determine the DP level, we next define the global sensitivity function for the operator g​(⋅)𝑔⋅g(\cdot) as

G​Sg=max𝒟,𝒟′⁡‖g​(𝒟)−g​(𝒟′)‖2,𝐺subscript𝑆𝑔subscript𝒟superscript𝒟′subscriptnorm𝑔𝒟𝑔superscript𝒟′2GS_{g}=\max_{\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}}\left\|g(\mathcal{D})-g(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\right\|_{2}, (5)

where 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} is a neighboring dataset of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. As mentioned in Section III, for uplink communications, we ensure that ‖𝗑tk‖2≤Csubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝗑𝑡𝑘2𝐶\left\|\mathsf{x}_{t}^{k}\right\|_{2}\leq C. Therefore, we have

G​Sg𝐺subscript𝑆𝑔\displaystyle GS_{g} =max𝒟,𝒟′⁡‖g​(𝒟)−g​(𝒟′)‖2=max𝗑tk,𝗑tk′⁡‖𝗑tk−𝗑tk′‖2≤max𝗑tk,𝗑tk′⁡[‖𝗑tk‖2+‖𝗑tk′‖2]≤2​C,absentsubscript𝒟superscript𝒟′subscriptnorm𝑔𝒟𝑔superscript𝒟′2subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝗑𝑡𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝗑𝑡𝑘′subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝗑𝑡𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝗑𝑡𝑘′2subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝗑𝑡𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝗑𝑡𝑘′subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝗑𝑡𝑘2subscriptnormsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝗑𝑡𝑘′22𝐶\displaystyle=\max_{\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}}\left\|g(\mathcal{D})-g(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\right\|_{2}=\max_{\mathsf{x}_{t}^{k},{\mathsf{x}_{t}^{k}}^{\prime}}\left\|\mathsf{x}_{t}^{k}-{\mathsf{x}_{t}^{k}}^{\prime}\right\|_{2}\leq\max_{\mathsf{x}_{t}^{k},{\mathsf{x}_{t}^{k}}^{\prime}}\left[\left\|\mathsf{x}_{t}^{k}\right\|_{2}+\left\|{\mathsf{x}_{t}^{k}}^{\prime}\right\|_{2}\right]\leq 2C, (6)

where 𝗑tk′superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝗑𝑡𝑘′{\mathsf{x}_{t}^{k}}^{\prime} denotes the noise-free model differential from client k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime} whose local dataset is swapped in a random data sample.

V-B Item-level Differential Privacy

The Rényi DP guarantee of FLORAS in a single learning round is given in Theorem 1.

Theorem 1.

Assume a spreading sequence set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} containing N𝑁N unique sequences and M𝑀M total clients involved in an FL task. In each learning round, K<min⁡{N,M}𝐾𝑁𝑀K<\min\{N,M\} clients are independently and uniformly randomly selected to participate in FL. With local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} of size D𝐷D and mini-batch size dbatch≜|ξ|<D≜subscript𝑑batch𝜉𝐷d_{\text{batch}}\triangleq|\xi|<D, FLORAS provides (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-Rényi DP for the global model, where

ϵ=12​α​log2⁡(1+q​p1+q​p​2​C​C2+γ2+2​C2γ2)=O​(α​q2​p2γ2),italic-ϵ12𝛼superscript21𝑞𝑝1𝑞𝑝2𝐶superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾22superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾2𝑂𝛼superscript𝑞2superscript𝑝2superscript𝛾2\epsilon=\frac{1}{2}\alpha\log^{2}\left(1+\frac{qp}{1+qp}\frac{2C\sqrt{C^{2}+\gamma^{2}}+2C^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}\right)=O\left(\frac{\alpha q^{2}p^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}\right), (7)

with q≜dbatchD+1−dbatch≜𝑞subscript𝑑batch𝐷1subscript𝑑batchq\triangleq\frac{d_{\text{batch}}}{D+1-d_{\text{batch}}}, p≜KM≜𝑝𝐾𝑀p\triangleq\frac{K}{M}, and γ=N−K𝛾𝑁𝐾\gamma=N-K.

Proof.

See Appendix A-B. ∎

Based on the composition rule of Rényi DP, we next establish the (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP guarantee for the overall uplink communications in an FL task of T𝑇T rounds.

Theorem 2.

Consider a wireless FL task with T𝑇T learning rounds, a spreading sequence set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} containing N𝑁N unique sequences, and K<min⁡{N,M}𝐾𝑁𝑀K<\min\{N,M\} clients are independently and uniformly randomly selected in each round. With local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} of size D𝐷D and mini-batch size dbatch<Dsubscript𝑑batch𝐷d_{\text{batch}}<D, FLORAS provides (ϵ′,δ)superscriptitalic-ϵ′𝛿(\epsilon^{\prime},\delta)-DP for the entire FL task, where

ϵ′superscriptitalic-ϵ′\displaystyle\epsilon^{\prime} =2​T​log⁡(1/δ)​log⁡(1+q​p1+q​p​2​C​C2+γ2+2​C2γ2)absent2𝑇1𝛿1𝑞𝑝1𝑞𝑝2𝐶superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾22superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾2\displaystyle=\sqrt{2T\log(1/\delta)}\log\left(1+\frac{qp}{1+qp}\frac{2C\sqrt{C^{2}+\gamma^{2}}+2C^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}\right)
+12​T​log2⁡(1+q​p1+q​p​2​C​C2+γ2+2​C2γ2)∼O~​(T​q​pγ),similar-to12𝑇superscript21𝑞𝑝1𝑞𝑝2𝐶superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾22superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾2~𝑂𝑇𝑞𝑝𝛾\displaystyle+\frac{1}{2}T\log^{2}\left(1+\frac{qp}{1+qp}\frac{2C\sqrt{C^{2}+\gamma^{2}}+2C^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}\right)\sim\tilde{O}\left(\frac{\sqrt{T}qp}{\gamma}\right), (8)

with q≜dbatchD+1−dbatch≜𝑞subscript𝑑batch𝐷1subscript𝑑batchq\triangleq\frac{d_{\text{batch}}}{D+1-d_{\text{batch}}}, p≜KM≜𝑝𝐾𝑀p\triangleq\frac{K}{M}, and γ=N−K𝛾𝑁𝐾\gamma=N-K.

Proof.

See Appendix A-C. ∎

Theorems 1 and 2 reveal that, for a given FL configuration, i.e., fixed number of selected clients K𝐾K, mini-batch size ratio q𝑞q, participation ratio p𝑝p, and the number of learning rounds T𝑇T, the expansion of spreading sequence set would achieve a higher level of DP per learning round and for the whole learning task, respectively. In particular, ϵ∝1γ2proportional-toitalic-ϵ1superscript𝛾2\epsilon\propto\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}} in Rényi DP for each learning round, and ϵ′∝1γproportional-tosuperscriptitalic-ϵ′1𝛾\epsilon^{\prime}\propto\frac{1}{\gamma} in (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP for the whole learning task. Since the BS (adversary) has no knowledge of which particular K𝐾K out of the total N𝑁N spreading sequences the clients have chosen, increasing the number of spreading sequences results in a heavier tail of the post-processing Cauchy noise, which achieves better privacy protection.

Guided by Theorem 2, we can adjust N𝑁N to meet the privacy requirement of a practical FL task. Note that larger noise (better privacy protection) will affect the convergence rate of FL, and we will discuss this impact in detail in Section VI.

Remark 4 (Choice of DP metrics).

Note that we use (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP to evaluate the overall DP guarantee of the FL task. The reason why we choose to utilize Rényi DP to analyze the DP guarantee per learning round is the same as [49]: we can obtain a tighter (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP guarantee from the composition of multiple Rényi-DP mechanisms. This advantage is empirically shown in Fig. 2, in which we compare the overall DP guarantees v.s. learning rounds of three different composition methods: i) vanilla sequential composition of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP; ii) advanced composition of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP; iii) (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP converted from composition of Rényi DP. It clearly demonstrates that under different system configurations, Theorem 2 unanimously provides the tightest (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP guarantee, which is consistent with the theoretical and experimental results in [48].

V-C Client-level Differential Privacy

So far, we have focused on the standard item-level DP that protects a single data sample of a certain local dataset. For FL, another DP concept called client-level DP (also known as user-level DP) is also important. The definition of client-level DP follows similarly from Definition 1, with a slight change that the neighboring dataset pair 𝒟∼𝒟′similar-to𝒟superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}\sim\mathcal{D}^{\prime} differs in at most all data samples of one single client. As a result, client-level DP protects privacy when the entire data from a certain client is swapped. Intuitively, this guarantees that the participation of a client cannot be inferred by observing the received signals.

From the previous discussion of global sensitivity, the output xtksuperscriptsubscriptx𝑡𝑘\textsf{x}_{t}^{k} is always bounded even though the entire dataset of a certain client changes. Therefore, our method intuitively satisfies the client-level DP, and we formally establish the following guarantee.

Theorem 3.

Given a spreading sequence set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} containing N𝑁N unique sequences, FLORAS provides (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-client level Rényi DP, when K𝐾K clients are independently and uniformly randomly selected from the total M𝑀M clients in each learning round, where

ϵ=12​α​log2⁡(1+p​2​C​C2+γ2+2​C2γ2)=O​(α​p2γ2).italic-ϵ12𝛼superscript21𝑝2𝐶superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾22superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾2𝑂𝛼superscript𝑝2superscript𝛾2\epsilon=\frac{1}{2}\alpha\log^{2}\left(1+p\frac{2C\sqrt{C^{2}+\gamma^{2}}+2C^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}\right)=O\left(\frac{\alpha p^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}\right). (9)

Moreover, for total T𝑇T learning rounds, FLORAS provides (ϵ′′,δ)superscriptitalic-ϵ′′𝛿(\epsilon^{\prime\prime},\delta)-client level DP for the entire FL task, where

ϵ′′superscriptitalic-ϵ′′\displaystyle\epsilon^{\prime\prime} =2​T​log⁡(1/δ)​log⁡(1+p​2​C​C2+γ2+2​C2γ2)absent2𝑇1𝛿1𝑝2𝐶superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾22superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾2\displaystyle=\sqrt{2T\log(1/\delta)}\log\left(1+p\frac{2C\sqrt{C^{2}+\gamma^{2}}+2C^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}\right)
+12​T​log2⁡(1+p​2​C​C2+γ2+2​C2γ2)∼O~​(T​pγ).similar-to12𝑇superscript21𝑝2𝐶superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾22superscript𝐶2superscript𝛾2~𝑂𝑇𝑝𝛾\displaystyle+\frac{1}{2}T\log^{2}\left(1+p\frac{2C\sqrt{C^{2}+\gamma^{2}}+2C^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}\right)\sim\tilde{O}\left(\frac{\sqrt{T}p}{\gamma}\right). (10)
Proof.

See Appendix A-D. ∎

Theorem 3 demonstrates that FLORAS provides the client-level DP guarantee in a manner that is similar to the item-level DP. However, since the entire local dataset of a certain client would be swapped, we cannot take advantage of the SGD randomness in the analysis of client-level DP. Therefore, q𝑞q disappears from the client-level DP guarantee.

V-D Spreading Sequence Assignment Mechanism

As we have discussed, the DP guarantee of FLORAS comes from the fact that the assignment of spreading sequences remains unknown to the BS (adversary). In traditional CDMA systems, the spreading sequence is assigned to each device by the BS. This mechanism becomes invalid in our setting, since we need to make sure that the BS only has knowledge of the spreading sequence set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, not the individual assignment. In practice, we can resort to a trusted third-party to handle the assignment of orthogonal sequences. The design of such a mechanism belongs to the field of secure multi-party computation (MPC) [50, 51] and is out of the scope of this paper.

In the following, we provide a preliminary reference design based on a random permutation algorithm as illustrated in Fig. 3. The proposed design allows each user to autonomously choose a unique spreading code without collision. To better explain the mechanism, we first define a fixed matrix based on 𝒜={𝐚k,k=1,⋯,N}:𝐀=[𝐚1,⋯,𝐚N]∈ℝL×N.\mathcal{A}=\{{\bf a}_{k},k=1,\cdots,N\}:{\bf A}=\left[{\bf a}_{1},\cdots,{\bf a}_{N}\right]\in\mathbb{R}^{L\times N}. We assume that every device that will be involved in the FL task shares a common confidential Key. This key is a priori knowledge to clients, yet confidential to the BS (adversary). This assumption can be achieved via standard cryptography approaches, e.g., the key-exchange protocol [52]. When the BS schedules clients to participate in the current learning round, an index ∈{1,⋯,K}absent1⋯𝐾\in\{1,\cdots,K\} will be assigned to each client. After that, every client leverages the confidential Key and the current system time SystemTime() to generate a random seed RandSeed(). Since the system has been synchronized, each client will obtain the same random seed, and generate a (common) random permutation matrix 𝐏π∈ℝN×Nsubscript𝐏𝜋superscriptℝ𝑁𝑁{\bf P}_{\pi}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times N} based on that. Followed by a random column permutation 𝐀~=𝐀𝐏π,~𝐀subscript𝐀𝐏𝜋\tilde{\bf A}={\bf A}{\bf P}_{\pi}, each client can use the index-th column 𝐀~~𝐀\tilde{\bf A}[:,index] as its spreading sequence for the current learning round. Note that as long as the confidential key is not leaked, the BS (adversary) will not know which K𝐾K of the total N𝑁N spreading sequences are adopted in the current learning round.

Remark 5.

We emphasize that the established DP guarantee is for the receiver processing proposed in Section IV-A. There may exist more sophisticated receiver algorithms, which could conceivably attempt to infer more information about the usage of the orthogonal sequences per learning round from the received signal. However, since we do not make any assumptions on the channel distribution, such approach would be difficult in general. Besides, it is impossible to always accurately identify all used sequences due to the channel noise. Therefore, even under this scenario, the proposed framework still provides privacy, although the DP guarantee dependency may decrease from O​(1/γ)𝑂1𝛾O(1/\gamma) to O​(1/(α​γ))𝑂1𝛼𝛾O(1/(\alpha\gamma)), where 0<α<10𝛼10<\alpha<1.

VI Convergence analysis

We analyze the ML model convergence behavior of FLORAS in this section. We first make the following standard assumptions that are commonly adopted in the convergence analysis of FedAvg and its variants; see [45, 53, 54, 5].

Assumption 1.

L𝐿L-smooth: ∀𝐯for-all𝐯\forall~{}\mathbf{v} and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, ‖fk​(𝐯)−fk​(𝐰)‖≤L​‖𝐯−𝐰‖normsubscriptfk𝐯subscriptfk𝐰Lnorm𝐯𝐰\left\|f_{k}({\bf v})-f_{k}({\bf w})\right\|\leq L\left\|{\bf v}-{\bf w}\right\|;

Assumption 2.

μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex: ∀𝐯for-all𝐯\forall~{}\mathbf{v} and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, ⟨fk​(𝐯)−fk​(𝐰),𝐯−𝐰⟩≥μ​‖𝐯−𝐰‖2subscriptfk𝐯subscriptfk𝐰𝐯𝐰μsuperscriptnorm𝐯𝐰2\left<f_{k}({\bf v})-f_{k}({\bf w}),{\bf v}-{\bf w}\right>\geq\mu\left\|{\bf v}-{\bf w}\right\|^{2};

Assumption 3.

Unbiased SGD: ∀k∈[M]for-allkdelimited-[]M\forall k\in[M], 𝔼​[∇f~k​(𝐰)]=∇fk​(𝐰)𝔼delimited-[]∇subscript~fk𝐰∇subscriptfk𝐰\mathbb{E}[\nabla\tilde{f}_{k}({\bf w})]=\nabla f_{k}({\bf w});

Assumption 4.

Uniformly bounded gradient: ∀k∈[M]for-allkdelimited-[]M\forall k\in[M], 𝔼​‖∇f~k​(𝐰)‖2≤H2𝔼superscriptnorm∇subscript~fk𝐰2superscriptH2\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla\tilde{f}_{k}({\bf w})\right\|^{2}\leq H^{2} for all mini-batch data.

The main challenge, and hence the novelty of our analysis, lies in the Cauchy distributed post-processing noise. We note that a Cauchy distribution has uncertain (infinity) variance. To address this issue, the BS applies a truncation operation in the interval [−B,B]𝐵𝐵[-B,B] on the decoded global parameters in (3), before de-normalization:

x~i≈max⁡(min⁡(∑k=1Kxki+∑k=K+1N𝐚kT​𝐧i𝐚kT​𝐧s,B),−B)subscript~𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘𝐾1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑘𝑇subscript𝐧𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑇𝑘subscript𝐧𝑠𝐵𝐵\tilde{x}_{i}\approx\max\left(\min\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}x_{k}^{i}+\sum_{k=K+1}^{N}\frac{{\bf a}_{k}^{T}{\bf n}_{i}}{{\bf a}^{T}_{k}{\bf n}_{s}},B\right),-B\right) (11)

where B≫Cmuch-greater-than𝐵𝐶B\gg C and C𝐶C is a normalization parameter defined in Section III-B. Note that the truncation operation is universal (albeit sometimes implicit) in almost all practical systems, since the signal values in the processing units are always finite. As a post-processing procedure, the truncation operation has no impact on the DP guarantee of FLORAS. Unfortunately, it will introduce a bias in the estimate x~isubscript~𝑥𝑖\tilde{x}_{i}, which impacts convergence. In particular, the equivalent noise after the limiting operation will be a truncated Cauchy distribution with support [−B−∑k=1Kxki,B−∑k=1Kxki]𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖[-B-\sum_{k=1}^{K}x_{k}^{i},B-\sum_{k=1}^{K}x_{k}^{i}]. Fortunately, as long as we ensure B≫Cmuch-greater-than𝐵𝐶B\gg C which requires a very mild truncation and thus is easy to satisfy, this operation will only have very limited impact on the received signal, hence does not significantly harm the convergence performance. We also note that biased gradients are very common in various DP-guaranteed SGD methods [32, 55, 56]. Moreover, after de-normalization, the biased term is effectively diminishing. Therefore, as we show in Theorem 4, FLORAS can still maintain a good convergence performance despite of the biased noise, which will also be numerically corroborated in Section VII.

Theorem 4.

With Assumptions 1-4 and μ>2​d​D​(γ)​E​H/K𝜇2𝑑𝐷𝛾𝐸𝐻𝐾\mu>2\sqrt{dD(\gamma)}EH/K, for some r≥0𝑟0r\geq 0, if we set the learning rate as ηt=2μ′​(t+r)subscript𝜂𝑡2superscript𝜇′𝑡𝑟\eta_{t}=\frac{2}{\mu^{\prime}(t+r)}, a wireless system implementing FLORAS achieves

𝔼​[f​(𝐰t)]−f∗≤L(t+r)​[4​Gμ′2+(1+r)​‖𝐰0−𝐰∗‖2],𝔼delimited-[]𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝑓𝐿𝑡𝑟delimited-[]4𝐺superscriptsuperscript𝜇′21𝑟superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2\begin{split}&\mathbb{E}[f({\bf w}_{t})]-f^{*}\leq\frac{L}{(t+r)}\left[\frac{4G}{{\mu^{\prime}}^{2}}+(1+r)\left\|{\bf w}_{0}-{\bf w}^{*}\right\|^{2}\right],\end{split}

for any t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1, where μ′≜μ−2​d​D​(γ)​E​H/K≜superscript𝜇′𝜇2𝑑𝐷𝛾𝐸𝐻𝐾\mu^{\prime}\triangleq\mu-2\sqrt{dD(\gamma)}EH/K,

G≜(1+2​d​D​(γ)K​E​H​η1)​(∑k=1MHk2M2+6​L​Γ+8​(E−1)2​H2+M−KM−1​4K​E2​H2)+4​d​D​(γ)K2​E2​H2.≜𝐺12𝑑𝐷𝛾𝐾𝐸𝐻subscript𝜂1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑘2superscript𝑀26𝐿Γ8superscript𝐸12superscript𝐻2𝑀𝐾𝑀14𝐾superscript𝐸2superscript𝐻24𝑑𝐷𝛾superscript𝐾2superscript𝐸2superscript𝐻2\small\begin{split}G\triangleq&\left(1+\frac{2\sqrt{dD(\gamma)}}{K}EH\eta_{1}\right)\left(\sum_{k=1}^{M}\frac{H_{k}^{2}}{M^{2}}+6L\Gamma+8(E-1)^{2}H^{2}+\frac{M-K}{M-1}\frac{4}{K}E^{2}H^{2}\right)+{\frac{4dD(\gamma)}{K^{2}}E^{2}H^{2}}.\end{split}

and

D​(γ)=γ2C2​arctan⁡(B+Cγ)​[Bγ−arctan⁡(B+Cγ)].𝐷𝛾superscript𝛾2superscript𝐶2𝐵𝐶𝛾delimited-[]𝐵𝛾𝐵𝐶𝛾D(\gamma)=\frac{{\gamma}^{2}}{C^{2}\arctan\left(\frac{B+C}{{\gamma}}\right)}\left[\frac{B}{{\gamma}}-\arctan\left(\frac{B+C}{{\gamma}}\right)\right].
Proof.

See Appendix B. ∎

Theorem 4 demonstrates that FLORAS preserves the O​(1/T)𝑂1𝑇O(1/T) convergence rate of SGD for strongly convex loss functions (compared with the noise-free FL convergence). For a fixed initial point, there are multiple factors in the constant G𝐺G that affect the convergence rate of FL. In particular, ∑k=1KHk2K2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑘2superscript𝐾2\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{H_{k}^{2}}{K^{2}} reveals the variance reduction effect of SGD by involving more clients, and 6​L​Γ6𝐿Γ6L\Gamma and 8​(E−1)2​H28superscript𝐸12superscript𝐻28(E-1)^{2}H^{2} capture the influence of non-IID dataset and the number of local epochs, respectively. We note that term D​(γ)𝐷𝛾D(\gamma) in G𝐺G demonstrates the impact from Cauchy noise, i.e. level of privacy protection. We also note that D​(γ)𝐷𝛾D(\gamma) is increasing as γ𝛾\gamma becomes larger. It implies that a higher level of privacy protection will decrease the speed of convergence as constant D​(γ)𝐷𝛾D(\gamma) becomes larger. Therefore, Theorem 4 establishes a tradeoff between privacy protection and convergence rate, which can guide the practical system design.

VII Experiments

In this section, we evaluate the performance of FLORAS through numerical experiments. We first compare the learning performance of FLORAS with the widely-investigated channel inversion AirComp method. Then, we evaluate the effect on the ML model convergence rate of various DP levels. In particular, we corroborate the theoretical results via real-world FL tasks on the MNIST dataset. The experiments demonstrate that FLORAS achieves superior performances under various SNRs and other system configurations.

Details on the setup of experiments are as follows. All convergence curves are the average of five independent Monte Carlo trials. The MNIST dataset contains multiple handwritten digit figures of 20×20202020\times 20 pixels. The training set contains 4,00040004,000 examples and is evenly distributed over K=20𝐾20K=20 clients. For the IID case, the data is shuffled and randomly assigned to each client; for the non-IID case, the data is sorted by labels and each client is randomly assigned with the data of one label. The test set size is 1,00010001,000. We evaluate FLORAS and validate the theoretical results on a multinomial logistic regression task. Specifically, let f​(𝐰;xi)𝑓𝐰subscript𝑥𝑖f({\bf w};x_{i}) denote the prediction model with the parameter 𝐰=(𝐖,𝐛)𝐰𝐖𝐛{\bf w}=({\bf W},{\bf b}) and the form f​(𝐰;xi)=softmax​(𝐖​xi+𝐛)𝑓𝐰subscript𝑥𝑖softmax𝐖subscript𝑥𝑖𝐛f({\bf w};x_{i})=\texttt{softmax}({\bf W}x_{i}+{\bf b}). The loss function is given by loss​(𝐰)=1D​∑i=1DCrossEntropy​(f​(𝐰;xi),𝐲i)+λ​‖𝐰‖2loss𝐰1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷CrossEntropy𝑓𝐰subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖𝜆superscriptnorm𝐰2\texttt{loss}({\bf w})=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{i=1}^{D}\texttt{CrossEntropy}(f({\bf w};x_{i}),{\bf y}_{i})+\lambda\left\|{\bf w}\right\|^{2}. We adopt the regularization parameter λ=0.01𝜆0.01\lambda=0.01 in the experiments.

VII-A Communication Efficiency

We first evaluate the performance of FLORAS compared with the channel inversion method. We assume IID Raleigh block fading channel hk∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,1),∀k=1,⋯,Kformulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptℎ𝑘𝒞𝒩01for-all𝑘1⋯𝐾h_{k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,1),\forall k=1,\cdots,K. For channel inversion, we adopt a user admission threshold 0.010.010.01 for the fading channel gain to avoid deep fading. The following parameters are used for training: local batch size 505050, the number of local epochs E=1𝐸1E=1, and learning rate η=0.005𝜂0.005\eta=0.005 and η=0.001𝜂0.001\eta=0.001 for the IID and non-IID case, respectively.

Fig. 4-(a) and Fig. 4-(b) illustrate the training loss and test accuracy performance versus learning round of FLORAS and channel inversion in high (red line) and low (blue) SNR regimes, respectively. For high SNR (151515 dB), FLORAS and channel inversion have similar performances. Although transmitter fading channel cancellation in channel inversion limits the maximum transmission power of each user, its performance does not deteriorate, since noise is not the dominant factor of the convergence. However, we note that, unlike FLORAS, channel inversion requires full CSIT at each client, which not only consumes larger communication overhead, but also increases the dynamic range of the signal, bringing higher hardware cost. The advantages of FLORAS become conspicuous in the low SNR regime (00 dB), in which noise becomes the dominant factor of the convergence rate. FLORAS allows all participated clients to make full use of transmit power and achieves significantly better performance. As shown in Fig. 4-(b), FLORAS achieves about 7.5%percent7.57.5\% higher test accuracy compared with channel inversion at SNR = 00 dB. This phenomenon becomes more notable in the non-IID dataset as shown in Fig. 4-(c) and Fig. 4-(d), where the performance gap of test accuracy between FLORAS and channel inversion further grows to 10.2%percent10.210.2\%.

VII-B Differential Privacy

We also evaluate the convergence performance versus different levels of DP. We keep SNR =20absent20=20 dB and number of selected user K=20𝐾20K=20, while changing the size of the orthogonal sequence set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} from 20,21,2520212520,21,25 to 303030, i.e., γ=0,1,5𝛾015\gamma=0,1,5 and 101010. In each learning round, each user selects its own signature from set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} via the method in Section V-D. As discussed in Section V, the larger size of set 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, the higher DP level FLORAS achieves. The following parameters are used for training: local batch size 202020, the number of local epochs E=1𝐸1E=1, and learning rate η=0.005𝜂0.005\eta=0.005 and η=0.001𝜂0.001\eta=0.001 for IID and non-IID cases, respectively. The training losses with different DP levels are illustrated in Fig. 5-(a) and Fig. 5-(c) of IID and non-IID cases, respectively. It is clear that although a higher privacy level decreases the convergence rate, the machine learning model can still converge with almost the same training loss as the no-differential-privacy case (γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0), which is consistent with the theoretical analysis in Section VI. The test accuracies in Fig. 5-(b) and Fig. 5-(d) further validate the effectiveness of FLORAS. We can see that the test accuracies for moderate DP levels (γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 and 555) are almost the same as the case of γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0, i.e., we can achieve certain DP levels almost for free. Even when γ=10𝛾10\gamma=10, the test accuracy loss is tiny, with about 3.5%percent3.53.5\% and 2.5%percent2.52.5\% compared with the γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 case in the IID and non-IID datasets, respectively.

VIII Conclusion

We have proposed FLORAS, a differentially private AirComp FL framework. Compared with the channel inversion method, FLORAS does not require CSIT and has much more robust performance in the low SNR regime, which is crucial for IoT applications. The flexibility of adjusting the size of the orthogonal sequence set allows us to control both item-level and client-level DP guarantees of the system. From the analyses of convergence and DP of FLORAS, we have established the tradeoff between convergence rate and privacy preservation, which has been further validated by experiments on real-world FL tasks.

A-D Proof of Theorem 3

Therefore, the mechanism ℳ​(𝒟)ℳ𝒟\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}) samples from the following distribution

ℳ​(𝒟)=1ψ​∑j=1ψ𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖼𝗁𝗒​(g​(𝒮j),γ​𝐈d).ℳ𝒟1𝜓superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝜓𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖼𝗁𝗒𝑔subscript𝒮𝑗𝛾subscript𝐈𝑑\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})=\frac{1}{\psi}\sum_{j=1}^{\psi}\textrm{$\sf{Cauchy}$}{}(g(\mathcal{S}_{j}),\gamma{\bf I}_{d}).

The proof of the client-level DP guarantee for the composition of T𝑇T rounds follows the same as that in Appendix A-C.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 4

With a slight abuse of notation, we change the timeline to be with respect to the overall SGD iteration time steps instead of the communication rounds, i.e.,

t=1,⋯,E⏟round 1,E+1,⋯,2​E⏟round 2,⋯,⋯,(T−1)​E+1,⋯,T​E⏟round T.𝑡subscript⏟1⋯𝐸round 1subscript⏟𝐸1⋯2𝐸round 2⋯⋯subscript⏟𝑇1𝐸1⋯𝑇𝐸round Tt=\underbrace{1,\cdots,E}_{\text{round 1}},\underbrace{E+1,\cdots,2E}_{\text{round 2}},\cdots,\cdots,\underbrace{(T-1)E+1,\cdots,TE}_{\text{round $T$}}.

Note that the global model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t} is only accessible at the clients for specific t∈ℐE𝑡subscriptℐ𝐸t\in\mathcal{I}_{E}, where ℐE={n​E|n=1,2,…}subscriptℐ𝐸conditional-set𝑛𝐸𝑛12…\mathcal{I}_{E}=\{nE~{}|~{}n=1,2,\dots\}, i.e., the time steps for communication. The notations for ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} are similarly adjusted to this extended timeline, but their values remain constant within the same round. B-A Lemmas

Lemma 5.

Let Assumptions 1-4 hold, ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} is non-increasing, and ηt≤2​ηt+Esubscript𝜂𝑡2subscript𝜂𝑡𝐸\eta_{t}\leq 2\eta_{t+E} for all t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0. If ηt≤1/(4​L)subscript𝜂𝑡14𝐿\eta_{t}\leq{1}/(4L), we have

𝔼​‖𝐯¯t+1−𝐰∗‖2≤(1−ηt​μ)​𝔼​‖𝐰¯t−𝐰∗‖2+ηt2​(∑k=1MHk2/M2+6​L​Γ+8​(E−1)2​H2).𝔼superscriptnormsubscript¯𝐯𝑡1superscript𝐰21subscript𝜂𝑡𝜇𝔼superscriptnormsubscript¯𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑘2superscript𝑀26𝐿Γ8superscript𝐸12superscript𝐻2\mathbb{E}\left\|\mathbf{\overline{v}}_{t+1}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\|^{2}\leq(1-\eta_{t}\mu)\mathbb{E}\left\|\mathbf{\overline{w}}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\|^{2}+\eta_{t}^{2}\left({\sum_{k=1}^{M}H_{k}^{2}}/{M^{2}}+6L\Gamma+8(E-1)^{2}H^{2}\right).

Lemma 5 establishes a bound for the one-step SGD. This result only concerns the local model update and is not impacted by the noisy communication. The derivation is similar to the technique in [54] and is omitted.

Lemma 6 demonstrates a bound for the uniformly random selection. This result bounded the extra “noise” brought by partial participation. Define v≜max⁡{4​Gμ′2,(1+r)​Δ1}≜𝑣4𝐺superscriptsuperscript𝜇′21𝑟subscriptΔ1v\triangleq\max\{\frac{4G}{{\mu^{\prime}}^{2}},(1+r)\Delta_{1}\}. By the L𝐿L-smoothness of f𝑓f and v≤4​Gμ′2+(1+r)​Δ1𝑣4𝐺superscriptsuperscript𝜇′21𝑟subscriptΔ1v\leq\frac{4G}{{\mu^{\prime}}^{2}}+(1+r)\Delta_{1}, we prove Theorem 4.
